title: issue-day-rise-moth
story: Why are they on the rise Itrsquos in part due to the warmer weather, but also the trend for eco-friendly wash cycles, which see clothes laundered in temperatures of C which is recommended as being better for the environment.Rentokil say, though, that moth larvae are only killed when in contact with water above C, so the low temperatures allow moth eggs to grow and hatch, boosting the population.How bad is the problem An estimated three and a half million households have been hit by moth infestations this year, with London and the south-east hardest hit, likely due to experiencing some of the highest temperatures.In all, since , Rentokil says the number of homes using its moth eradication service has rocketed by  per cent.How did the issue first come to light The National Trust reported a rise in moths caught between  and . Earlier this year, the National Trust for Scotlandrsquos Newhailes House, near Musselburgh, East Lothian, called in lsquomothbustersrsquo to help protect the th century propertyrsquos historic collection.What did the lsquomothbustersrsquo do NTS experts combined a deep clean with a deep freeze, installing two industrial freezers - each the size of shipping crates - at the property.What do the moths do There are around , moth species in the UK, but its primarily the common clothes moths that cause issues. They are notorious for feeding on clothing and natural fibres, especially wool, fur, silk, feathers, felt, and leather. These materials contain keratin, a fibrous protein that the worm-like larvae of the clothes moth can digest. They are also known to favour handmade rugs because its easier for the larvae to get underneath and do their damage.How can you stop moths from infesting your home Top tips to prevent infestations include keeping items you treasure in vacuum packed bags to stop moths from gaining access, decluttering wardrobes of clothes not often worn and vacuuming everywhere you can reach - even inside wardrobes.Any other tips Opening windows to allow air to circulate during warm weather and turning off the radiators is advised, as is taking clothes out of your cupboards and giving them a shake regularly to disturb any moths present. Experts also suggest caution when buying second hand items.Some people even keep clothes in the freezer TV presenter Kirstie Allsopp said last year that moths are "the bane of my le," admitting to keeping a small freezer next to her washing machine to keep her scarves and woollen coats safe.She said: ldquoI constantly put things in to freeze the eggs and stop them in their tracks."And having spent a huge amount of money on products and pest-controllers, she said she learned the hard way that "the only way to keep your home moth-free is constant vigilance".ends

title: scotland-move-join-eu-seriously-considered-says-van-rompuy
story: Herman Van Rompuy said there was now "much more sympathy" for European regions seeking EU membership.And Mike Russell, Scotlands constitutional relations secretary believes there is now a path open for an independent Scotland to "walk into" EU membership.Mike Russell said there has been a "huge change" in the EUs attitude towards Scotland, where % of people voted remain in the  referendum.In the independence referendum of September , , % voted against becoming an independent country.The UK government does not support Scottish government calls for another independence referendum.:Poll finds UK-wide support for second independence and Northern Irish border referendum that could break up unionBut a new BMG survey found that % of people in England, Scotland and Wales believe the Government should allow a second referendum on the issue of Scottish independence, while % were against the idea.When "dont knows" are removed the split is % in support of a referendum and % against, according to the poll of , people.Mr Van Rompuy told the BBC the process ofjoining the EU was "complicated" but that an application from Scotland would have to be "very seriously" considered."I think there is a change, yes, because for a lot of people they are looking at what Scottish people are in favour of," he said."They want to stay in the European Union and at the same time they are prevented to stay in the European Union because there is this Brexit case, and there is not much sympathy for the Brexit case in the European Union, not among the leaders and not among the men and women in the street."Mr Van Rompuy said that the result of any Scottish independence referendum would have to be considered by the EUit had been legally agreed and was constitutional.He also said that all  member states would have to agree for Scotland to join.Mr Russell added: "There is a sea change in attitude. There is no solidarity with the UK, the UK has, of course, behaved pretty appallingly towards the EU and in those circumstances, they look at Scotland, they look at our desire to be in the EU and they understand that so there is a huge change."The EU is a rules-based organisation, thats something the UK doesnt understand so there are rules to be gone through, nobody has ever denied that, but what this does is it places us on the same footing as anybody  and in actual fact in a better position because we have observed the rules of the EU for the last  plus years."We know what those rules are and we can meet them so this essentially means there is a path open to an independent Scotland to be a normal European country, something which I think many people will be pleased about.""@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Countdown to Brexit:  days until Britain leaves the EU","description": "Countdown to Brexit:  days until Britain leaves the EU","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media RfOTIKsM poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests RfOTIKsM.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": :Willie Rennie: Indyref should be blocked eventhe SNP Greens win Holyrood electionAsked whether it would still be a policy for Scotland to become a full member of the EUit were to become independent he replied: "There is a path open for Scotland to walk into EU membership."There are of course things to be done, there is a great deal of hard work but it can be done and that is the big issue."Scotlands First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has already said she wants to have another referendum on leaving the UK in the second half of , however, Prime Minister Boris Johnson has stated his opposition to a second vote on the issue.Scottish Secretary Alister Jack said: "There are very real questions about whether an independent Scotland would be able to re-join the EU, not least because Scotlands notional deficit is more than double that allowed under EU rules."I am very clear that Scotlands future is better served by staying in the United Kingdom, keeping the pound, retaining control over our democratic rights, and having control over our own fishing waters."In  people in Scotland voted decisively to remain part of the United Kingdom."The Scottish Government promised it would be a once-in-a-generation decision. They must respect the result of the referendum."

title: health-boards-gas-move-aims-reduce-carbon-footprint
story: NHS Greater Glasgow and Clydeuses a signicant amount of the gases used to put patients to sleep for surgery but is expected to save up to pound, per year by introducing a lower carbon alternative.Sevoflurane is  times less polluting than desflurane, the hydrocarbon gas that was used as standard until recently.:How green is your council area  We reveal the reality of Scotlands carbon footprint hellip and the results might surprise youAfter use, anaesthetic gases are released into the atmosphere with desflurane having a global warming potential that is  times higher than sevoflurane.The gases represent an estimated five per cent of the carbon footprint for all acute NHS organisations.Desflurane stays in the atmosphere for around  years - almost  more than its alternative, which lasts for just over a year.Aside from the price and environmental cost, there is little dference between the two, although desflurane may still be required in some instances.NHSGCC anaesthetists concerned about the environmental impact of desflurane launched a Quality Improvement Project to promote sevoflurane as a safe alternative for most patients.NHS Highland has seen a % reduction in desflurane use since January and have slashed their anaesthesia bill by pound,.Dr Geraldine Gallagher, consultant anaesthetist at Glasgow Royal Infirmary and advisor to the project, said: ldquoClinically there is not a lot to choose from between the two anaesthetic gases. Because desflurane has a much more profoundly deleterious effect on the environment, in most situations it makes sense to choose sevoflurane.In surgeries that require a long anaesthetic, desflurane is the better choice because it is released from a patientrsquos body more quickly than the lower carbon alternative - allowing them to wake up more quickly.:Glasgow moots climate bondsDr Gallagher added: ldquoWhat wersquove tried to is make sure all our anaesthetic colleagues make an informed choice when theyrsquore deciding which one to use andthey do use desflurane it is because of sound clinical reasons and not just because itrsquos there.Other options to put patients to sleep include intravenous anaesthetics, which have even less impact on the environment.It has been estimated that one bottle of desflurane emits the same amount of co - one tonne- as a daily  mile round trip made by car for  weeks of the year.A recent study, published in The Lancet Planetary Health journal, highlights the potential for reducing emissions in health care settings and, at the same time, potentially reducing costs. Emissions due to anaesthetic gases accounted for approximately , tonnes of COe at two North American sites ndash ten-fold higher than the anaesthetic gas emissions from the UK hospital. The authors say this is largely the result of a higher usage of desflurane in the two North American hospitals.Dr Stephen Young, consultant anaesthetist, said ldquoThis is a really signicant environmental change, with a carbon dioxide equivalent reduction of  less cars commuting to the hospital every day. We have done this whilst maintaining high standards of anaesthetic care to our patients.ldquoIt has been estimated that five per cent of carbon dioxide equivalentemissions from acute hospitals are due to the use of inhalational agents. This is equivalent to around half the CO used to heat all hospital buildings and water.ldquoThis is just one of the areas in which NHSGGC is driving forward a focus on sustainability and making a dference to its carbon footprint.Dr Cathy Lawson is the National Fellow for Sustainable Anaesthesia for the Association of Anaesthetists and the Centre for Sustainable Health Care in collaboration with the Newcastle Upon Tyne hospitals.In her role, Dr Lawson works towards implementing sustainable systems within anaesthesia, encouraging doctors and hospitals to consider their environmental footprint by considering alternatives to established practices.One of the initiatives devised by the fellowship is to build the Environmental Champions Network comprised of one anaesthetist volunteer from every hospital in the UK and Ireland so that information can be shared.Dr Lawson said: ldquoWe know that people are starting to embed sustainability and sustainable projects within anaesthesia and therersquos been some really great work done and some really good ideas.ldquoWhat we hope the network will achieve is to help promote the work that people have done locally on a national scale so that people can see what projects have happened around the country and think they could do them too.Eventually, the network will be used to collect national data sets and get more information from hospitals so the fellowship can work on more concrete data and less estimates.Dr Lawson said: ldquoIf we have more accurate data we can get more accurate values of carbon foot-printing from some of our areas of practice that we know are high carbon impact.She echoes Dr Gallagher by saying that patient safety must always come first, and that will sometimes mean using less the sustainable desflurane gas.There are other initiatives being investigated that can lower emissions including recycling schemes and waste distribution. Dr Lawson said: ldquoAnaesthetics and theatres are a really resource intensive area of a hospital with lots of staff, lots of equipment, we use a lot of medication and we use a lot of water, energy and light.ldquoAs an industry, wersquore really trying to step up in terms of sustainability and looking at the products that are coming into the supply chain and in hospitals in the first place. Making sure they are sustainable, reusable, where possible, and not going to compromise any patient safety.

title: scotlands-biggest-local-government-pension-fund-facing-climate-call
story: The giant Strathclyde fund has been urged to drop all fossil fuel extraction assets from its multi-billion-pound portfolio from a working group set up by its biggest contributor, Glasgow council.The city has ambitious plans to become the first in the UK to get to zero-net carbon, when it takes out as much of the greenhouse gas from the atmosphere as it puts in.A working group set up to help the city achieve its aims has called for estment.In a major report, it said: ldquoAnother major issue in relation to finance is that of pension fund investments in fossil fuel extraction.ldquoThe working group heard proposals for a programme of estment from such activities and learned of a growing body of experience from organisations which have done this.ldquoThey include major funds within our own city, such as the pension fund for the University of Glasgow.ldquoWe have done this kind of thing before in moving away from investments in the tobacco industry and arms manufacturers, so we can do it again and we should do it for hydrocarbons. We commend the recent call from West Dunbartonshire Council for such action and recommend that Glasgow City Council works with the other employers and members to make a wholesale sht away from investment in hydrocarbons.ldquoWe recognise that there is an increasing risk of stranded assets which could undermine the performance of Strathclyde Pension Fund in years ahead.The fund is independent. Its spokesman said: ldquoStrathclyde Pension Fund is a strong supporter of the transition to a low carbon economy and has put climate change at the heart of its responsible investment strategy.ldquoAny pension fund should welcome engaged and committed members and we agree on the threat posed by climate change now and in the future. The fund has been a leader in terms of measuring its own carbon exposure ndash which is below average.ldquoIt is also progressively de-carbonising by shting investment to renewable energy and by working together with other investors to demand better standards from industry.He added: Strathclyde Pension Fund is recognised as one of the worldrsquos most active investors in addressing climate change."The independent Asset Owners Disclosure Projectranks the fund among the top asset owners globally for the disclosure and management of climate risk.It looks at three key areas: engagement, to gauge how investors are influencing the transition to a Low-Carbon economy risk, to assess how well owners are measuring the climate change risk within their portfolios, and investment in low-carbon assets.ldquoIn , the fund was in the top five performing asset owners in the UK ndash and the best performing Local Government scheme.An English council, Waltham Forest Council, was the first to announce estment. However, it still has millions of pounds in shares of big oil firms.Norwayrsquos  trillion-pound national fund is esting from oil and gas - source of much of its initial capital.Earlier this year there were suggestions public-sector pension funds should throw some of their financial weight behind reforesting.

title: opinion-matrix-little-sympathy-ex-pm-cameron
story: The Sunday TimesThe paper championed gaining exclusive extracts from Mr Cameronrsquos memoirs in which there was criticism for Boris Johnson for backing Leave ldquoto help his political career, with the ex-PM describing Cabinet minister Michael Gove as a ldquofoam-flecked Faragist. The pair were ldquoambassadors for the expert-trashing, truth-twisting age of populism, Mr Cameron wrote.But the paperrsquos editorial says that while it is ldquonatural he is now hitting out at his former friends and colleagues... he has only himselfto blame.It was Mr Cameron who decided to have a referendum over continued membership of the EU and then when Brexit was victorious in , stepped down.It was not the result he assured other EU leaders he would get, the Sunday Times said.ldquoThe EU referendum is not Mr Cameronrsquos only legacy, but it sums up his defects in office: a politician who always thought he could wing it by swotting up at the last minute when serious and sustained application was needed, saidthe editorial.ldquoMany millions of people, it should be said, are gratefulMr Cameron accidentally gave this country the Brexit they had long craved. They will not thank him, however, for the chaos left inhis wake.The Mail On SundayThere was little sympathy forMr Cameron in its editorial, in which the former PM is accused of failure ldquoat any stage to realise ldquojust how little he knew of the world outside his own magic circle.The leader stated: ldquoAnd so, when he was wafted into office on a cloud of skilful public relations and little , he lightly dismissed the huge, unavoidable European issue as a boring ersion about which people should stop lsquobanging onrsquo. And this was why it caught him in its talons and tore him apart.ldquoWhat do we learn from this  That there has been for many years a type of politician in this countryndash in all major parties ndash who has sneered at what he did not understand.ldquoThe era when such people could claim to rule us by effortless superiority has gone, for it turns out they were only lucky, not clever. The EU crisis swept that away.The ObserverAs the Liberal Democratsrsquo autumn conference got under way at Bournemouth, Andrew Rawnsley, the paperrsquos chief political commentator, examined Ms Swinsonrsquos credentials to transform the partyrsquos fortunes with the voters.He believed she is ldquostill a blank page fot most of the electorate and that the LibDemsrsquo fortunes will rely on how she performs on the election campaign trail and ldquono one can be sure about that until she is put to the test.The former Tory universities minister Sam Gyimah is the latest to switch to the Liberal Democrats, which, Mr Rawnsley said, would ldquoembolden optimistic LibDems to think that we are on the cusp of a big realignment of our politics, the breaking of the blue-red duopoly that has controlled Britain for decades.He added: ldquoThe allegiance-smashing forces unleashed by Brexit certainly seem to have created the most promising outlook in decades. Ms Swinson likes to think so, saying lsquothe faultline in British politics is no longer a left-right ide... now [it] is between liberal and authoritarian valuesrsquo.ldquoI am old enough to recall Paddy Ashdown saying similar things back in the s, only for the big old beasts of blue and red to recover and reassert their dominance. The truth is we just donrsquot know yet.The IndependentIt believes Ms Swinsonrsquos call to her party to commit to revokingArticle  was possibly ldquomore of a statement of intent ndash an opening bid in inter-party negotiations in a hung parliament.The online paperrsquos leader believes a new referendum ldquois the only way to reverse the  vote.ldquoThat referendum could take place before a general election, as Tony Blair, Mr Watson and others have argued. It may be that Mr Johnson,he fails to take Britain out of the EU at the end of next month, would rather have a referendum than fight an election with Nigel Farage on his back.ldquoButthere is an election, all Remainers in all parties should be as united as possible in using that election to obtain a Final Say referendum.ldquoThat will mean parties working together in unprecedented ways.

title: apples-foraging-pippins-clyde-valley
story: The names may be far more evocative than plain old Gala or Golden Delicious, and their tastes were certainly erse ndash from sugary sweet to be plucked and eaten straight from the tree, to small and sour crab apples that draw the cheeks together.The valleyrsquos rich heritage of nurturing orchards stuffed with dozens of ieties of apples was eventually chewed up and spat out by supermarkets, cheap imports and changing tastes.Now, however, as apple harvest season builds to a peak, fresh efforts are underway to encourage consumers, gardeners and cooks to rethink how we buy, eat and grow the humble apple.Just days ago, a group of foragers explored one of the few thriving orchards at the heart of the Clyde Valley, an area which once supplied the central belt with crate after crate piled high with juicy apples bearing names like Scotch Dumpling, James Grieve ndash named after their th century apple breeder - and White Melrose, plums, pears and soft fruits.As well as looking back to an age when the Clyde Valleyrsquos fruit trees covered hundreds of hectares of land, provided work and even influenced local culture through songs and harvest celebrations, the foragers discovered how to take advantage of the apple treesrsquo crops.The event also focused on efforts in the area to revive orchards, and ensure future generations can enjoy at least a flavour of the once glorious apple blossom which swathed the valley in colour each spring and a taste of homegrown fruits.The apple walk waspart of Scotlandrsquos first Foraging Fortnight, a new festival featuring a wide range of food and outdoor events across five regions: from Lanarkshirersquos apple orchards, to foraging for seaweed on Morayrsquos beaches and exploring traditional plant-based medicines in Orkney. Foraging programmes of events will also take place across Forth Valley and Lomond, and in Fe.Throughout the festival,participants foraged for and learn about medicinal plants, how to cook with wild ingredients and indulge in feasts made from foraged food.As well as fungi hunts, hedgerow and wildflower walks, the Lanarkshire programme offeredforagers the chance to explore Kirkfieldbank Community Orchard, where more than  trees have been planted by Clyde Valley Orchards Cooperative Limited, which represents the remaining apple growers in the area.The event, according to the organisationrsquos director Duncan Arthur, who lead the walk, aimed to highlight a lost age of apple-growing and attempts to keep alive a flavour of some of the arearsquos apple industry and its social impact.The valley, he says, was once richly decorated with the sweet-smelling blossoms and fruits of countless trees.ldquoApples in Scotland go away back to Roman times when they were introduced, but their hey day was about  years ago when there was a marked increase in the land given over to orchards, he says.ldquoThey grew Victoria plums which suited area well. Scottrsquos jam-makers were in Carluke, and crops of gooseberries were used for their pectin to make strawberry jam.ldquoThere were strawberries, soft fruits, damsons, and then came plums, apples and pears.Hundreds of orchards sprung up in large estates, delivering fruit to jam producers and markets. At the dawn of the th century, there were more than  hectares of commercial orchards throughout the Clyde and Avon Valley.Growers had found the valleyrsquos sheltered slopes, well-drained soils and moderate rainfall ideal for fruit growing. While the location - handy for large areas of population ndash meant they could easily transport their stock to fruit markets and shops.However the closure of railways followed by the s arrival of supermarkets with their demands for perfect-shaped fruits, cheaper imports, changing demand for sweeter, crisper, prettier fruit, saw many orchards wither and the land go fallow.The apple industry, which as well as providing jobs and income to the area brought cultural aspects in songs, stories and art, crumbled.A recent study of  of Clyde Valleyrsquos orchards sites found just over half were still intact, covering an area of just over  hectares. But while there was still signicant fruit grown in the area, most was not used, with around ha of orchard lost or abandoned.Of the trees that remained, many were aged with most orchards found to have less than  trees remaining.However an effort by the Co-operative has led to new trees being planted in private orchards and the Kirkgatefield Community Orchard Juice from the crops is now collected and sold to help fund further planting.However, Mr Arthur adds that the notion of the area once again providing signicant input to the nationrsquos apple harvest is unlikely.ldquoOur overall objective is tothe character and environmental benefits that came with the orchards and not lose any more of what were traditional orchards to development and neglect.ldquoDferent native ieties of apples is a nice thing to have, but what is really important to the area and the environment is to have trees which support other things like pollination, bugs, fungus and mosses.According to Wendy Barrie, cook and publisher of the Scottish Food Guide, the loss of much of Scotlandrsquos apple heritage has impacted on the way we cook as well as eat.ldquoScotland was world-famous for our apples and the orchards in places like Clyde Valley as well as at Newburgh in Fe and the Carse of Gowrie between Perth and Dundee, supplied an incredible range of ieties.ldquoWhat we get the supermarkets today is poor in comparison, she says.The bountul crops found their way into countless dishes, relishes and jams which helped add flavour to Scotsrsquo plates long after the last apple had been picked.ldquoBack in days gone by we didnrsquot have lemons from Sicily to provide flavour and sharpness, and apples were an important part of cooking, she adds.ldquoThey also provided pectin as a jellying agent for jams, and there were many uses for the apples they grew.She adds: ldquoTherersquos no one answer as to why our orchards have gone. Supermarkets, world trade, we import cheap appeals from New Zealand and France, while we could be growing our own. ldquoldquoWe need to keep heritage ieties alive.

title: doug-allens-life-lens
story: But despite his globe-trotting adventure, Fe-born wildle camera Doug Allan believes his native country remains one the most beautul in the world and the perfect place to learn how to e.And he says that his homeland is ahead of England in terms of tackling the issue of single-use plastics, one of two big problems facing the planet.Mr Allan, originally from Dunfermline, has travelled the world working on TV series including Blue Planet and Frozen Planet.The Scottish Government has made a commitment to ban plastic straws by the end of the year, while also introducing a depositscheme for some drinks containers.Speaking before another trip to the Arctic to film, the -year-old, who now lives in England, said the devolved Government in his homeland was ldquoahead of the curve.Doug films a whaleHe said: ldquoWersquove got two big issues that have been highlights recently.ldquoDavid Attenborough in Blue Planet  undoubtedly brought plastics to the forefront, which was a huge thing that needed to be done.:Floating Antarctic ice goes from record high to record lowsldquoThere are now Government initiatives to stop so much waste, but also to develop new plastics, which will be totally biodegradable or totally recyclable so that we donrsquot end up just ditching so much.ldquoThe Scottish Government in particular are ahead of the curve in terms of bringing in bottle deposits, all that sort of thing, and banning single-use plastics, straws. Scotland are ahead of England in that respect.He added: ldquoNow wersquove finally begun to become aware of climate change, which in its way is the biggest issue facing the planet because itrsquos going to affect all of us and every environment that we know of.ldquoIt may be the UK sitting where it does between - degrees north that has always had a iable climate we can maybe cope with some of it, but I donrsquot know how we cope with sea level rises, which could be a long-term problem.Initially an industrial er, Mr Allan graduated and did ious jobs, including a stint in the Red Sea with a group of biologists and working for a year with Bill Abernethy, who was Scotlandrsquos last full-time professional pearl fisherman.It was while working in the Antarctic that he made the switch to filming the natural world, after encountering a BBC crew making a documentary.Filming in the ArcticHe explained: ldquoIt was a chance meeting with David Attenborough, of all people, in . He turned up in our base with a small film crew.ldquoI helped him for a couple of days and quite literally at the end of those two days I looked at the cameraman and thought, lsquoyou know, you are doing all the things I like doingrsquo.ldquoEven though at that point I had not picked up a movie camera thatrsquos more or less where I thought thatrsquos what I want to be.ldquoDavid and the others were really helpful, gave me a bit of advice and things.The cameraman,who has won five Baftas and four Emmys, also praised Scotland when comparing its seas to the cleanliness of other areas he has travelled to.:Plastic pollution a catastrophe, says Sir David Attenborough#He said: ldquoI thinkyou learn to e in Scotland and then you pile into several hundred es to experience the weather, the cold all these kind of things then ... everything  is almost straightforward. Except of course ing under the ice.ldquoIrsquove seen the world encompass some big changes, but Irsquove also seen the world at its very best and itrsquos funny you know I sometimes get asked whatrsquos on your bucket list, where would you like to go next. Irsquom looking forward to spending more time in the UK... particularly Scotland and the west coast of Ireland.ldquoWhen those two are at their best they are unsurpassable. It really is the most beautul scenery on our doorstep.The Scot is also planning his own piece about climate change in the Arctic and willto Antarctica next year with the Peruvian navy to film their new research vessel.Mr Allan said: ldquoIn terms of my passions, what I do, everything started with ing and ing has been at the core of what Irsquove done during the whole of my career.ldquoPeople say to me lsquotell us something about your career pathrsquo and I say, lsquowell itrsquos not so much a career path as much as a careering pathrsquo.ldquoItrsquos just flowed from one interest to the next andI hadnrsquot met David I probably would still be doing stills photography and writing but I may not have gone into television.:Sir David Attenborough warns climate change will cause great social unrest#Mr Allan is also the new ambassador for Old Pulteneyrsquos ldquoRise With The Tide campaign, with the whisky highlighting its coastal roots by following the stories of those whose lives have been shaped by the sea.Malcom Waring, Pulteney Distillery manager, said: ldquoMeeting Doug was like meeting a kindred spirit. He understands perfectly how the sea can be embraced for the betterment of people, place and product, and thatrsquos a value we hold dear here at Pulteney.

title: football-clubs-lend-support-campaign-period-poverty
story: Eighteen months on and their dream has evolved into a movement with  clubs now on board. They call themselves On The Ball and theyrsquore exactly that.Period poverty is a serious issue in this country. A survey in  by Plan International found that as many as one in  girls and women aged between  and  in the UK were unable to afford sanitary products, with  per cent having to improvise with toilet roll, socks and even newspapers.A similar study by the Big Bloody Brunch found that more than one-quarter of women had been forced to miss work or school because they could not afford the necessary products.Where better to start solving the problem, thought Erin Slaven, Orlaith Duffy and Mikaela McKinley, than football  Lelong followers of the Parkhead club, the trio launched a petition in March  and shortly afterward received word that Celtic Park would be ldquoOn The Ball.:More than  million free sanitary products delivered in lsquoperiod povertyrsquo schemeFrom there, theyrsquove reached clubs across the world ndash including LA Galaxy, Altonear FC in Germany, Rangers, Liverpool, and West Ham ndash hitting the magic  mark thanks to Irish side Droghheda United.ldquoWe never imagined wersquod get to  clubs on board, said Ms Slaven, a -year-old social sciences graduate from Glasgow Caledonian University.ldquoI remember getting to five clubs and being so surprised, but itrsquos just spiralled out of control and itrsquos such a thrill. We said from the start that we hoped football leading the way would get people taking our campaign into their own lives and implement it in whatever way they can ndash in pubs and restaurants and things like that.ldquoWe always get asked things like, lsquoIf you can afford a ticket, can you not afford tampons rsquo but we feel like football is such a big business, itrsquos all about money and influence, so why not use that influence to make a dference.ldquoFootball clubs taking a lead on this puts the spotlight on period poverty and makes people aware of what is a real complex issue for many people.The group focused on four main campaign aims ndash to get clubs to provide free period products increase the visibility and voice of female fans remove the stigma around periods and raise awareness of period poverty.Their success has not come without a cost ndash with the group being tormented on social media at times.ldquoFootball is traditionally a male-dominated sport, so we thoughtwe can work with other fans who are predominantly female to make a change to increase the visibility of them and their needs, Ms Slaven continued.ldquoI think the needs of female fans has been overlooked until we stepped up and put it on their radar.ldquoWe knew it was a bit radical to go into a male-dominated environment and talk about periods, but we thought it would be effective and help remove the stigma and put it into public consciousness. We have had some really mad comments ndash people asking things like, lsquoWhere is my shaving foam, wherersquos the free pints and the pies rsquo These are all things woman use as well, might I add.:Hey Girlsrsquo phenomenal success sees it close in on aim of ending period poverty#ldquoSometimes we reply to comments, but we approach it in a way to educate people and share our views while acknowledging the fact they wonrsquot always agree.ldquoBy doing that, wersquove actually managed to change some peoplesrsquo minds after getting into healthy debates. For modern day social media that is amazing  ndash people donrsquot admit that theyrsquore wrong or have changed their minds.News that the group hit  clubs came exactly six months on from a new world-leading government scheme to provide free sanitary products in schools, colleges and universities.In that time, more than eight million products were handed out ndash backed by pound million of government funding.Since its inception, On The Ball has had the backing of Labour MSP Monica Lennon ndash who, as Ms Duffy put it, is ldquoleading the charge in terms of period poverty in parliament.Monica Lennon MSP said: ldquoAccess to period products at football grounds is the new normal thanks to the tenacious On the Ball campaign.ldquoI congratulate them on this big milestone ndash  clubs in such a short space of time is a fantasticachievement.ldquoThe clubs themselves should be applauded for signing up to this. My memberrsquos bill to make free universal access to period products the law in Scotland will be considered by MSPs soon and itrsquos exciting to see progressive social change already happening in our communities.The group are now taking steps to venture away from just football ndash spreading their message to youth groups and community clubs, as well as getting bars and restaurants ldquoOn The Ball.:Scotland could be world leader by offering free sanitary products#Ms Slaven continued: ldquoWersquore so passionate about making this an example of bottom-up change and the fans have made this possible.ldquoWhat wersquove loved about the campaign is to be able to work with other fans and keep it as grassroots as possible.ldquoThe past year or so wersquove increased our amount of work in communities too so we want to keep doing that, working with fans and local communities and youth groups too and just to help raise awareness about the issue.ldquoWersquoll still be focusing on football but wersquove had people come to us from ious bars and pubs and wersquove worked with them as well. As football fans theyrsquove seen the impact its had there and wanted to implement it in their workplace - and wersquore always more than happy to work with them.Commenting on the success of On The Ball, after giving them the drive to progress to other clubs, a spokesperson from Celtic added: ldquoWhen we were approached on this issue we were delighted to engage with the group on this project and of course we are delighted to become the first Club in the UK to offer such a service.ldquoWe congratulate Erin, Mikaela and Orlaith for all their work in this area and wish them every success on their wider, ongoing campaign.

title: letters-let-snp-now-publish-yellowhammer-equivalent-independence
story: Economists agree that their Growth Commission report describing the years following separation would lead to a decade of super-austerity with big tax increases and major public expenditure cuts. That is the median outlook. But whatthey are wrong  Whatin the worst case scenario we would also face power cuts, visa requirements to enter England at an international border with customs checks, lorries queued for miles on the M at Greta and the A at Berwick and the Venezuelaisation of the economy Whatrsquos sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander. So, Mr Blackford and Ms Sturgeon when can we have a worst case scenario for Scottish independence published William Loneskie, Lauder.IT does appear that the continuing Brexit saga has unwittingly highlighted flaws and limitations in both our constitutional and parliamentary process. Surely the misnomer United Kingdom should be replaced by United Kingdoms , although some might suggest Disunited Kingdom is even more apt.It appears Boris Johnsonrsquos deputation sought audience with the Queen at Balmoral hence any decisions reached would be subject to the laws of the land . Not surprisingly, the prorogation objections were upheld by three Court of Session Law Lords. At best Balmoral was an ill-chosen venue but, more importantly, who advised the Queen on the not-inconsiderable ramications of her authorisation being granted  Instead of ldquowas Mr Johnson economical with the truth hellip surely the evidence of those present should be obtained and made public Allan C Steele, Gfnock.THE ruling in Scotlandrsquos highest court regarding the illegality of proroguing Parliament by the Prime Minister appears to have caused a lot of anti-Scottish sentiment south of the Border.Why is it that when the UK is leaving the EU, it is said they are ldquotaking back our independence and taking back control of our laws. Nigel Farage has said that when we leave the EU, it will be ldquoour independence day. But when Scottish Nationalist politicians mention and state how good independence would be for Scotland, they are classed as separatists, breaking up the Union. Surely what is good for the goose is good for the gander.Robert McCaw, Renfrew.I FEEL that David Cameron is a little wrong in seemingly shouldering the blame, or at least the feeling of guilt, for Brexit, as recent revelations would suggest .We can oust politicians at a general election we can behead kings we can exile emperors we can shoot dictators, but in a democracy we are stuck with those in power, namely the voting public.The main and indeed overwhelming problem with democracy is that the people who vote in a referendum are completely devoid of accountability. A voting democracy is a secret society of iniduals. I, who voted to remain in the EU, will be continuing to feel aggrieved that we are leaving due to the misinformed views of only % of the electorate, who were foolish enough to believe the lie painted on the side of a bus. It is no use pleading they didnrsquot know Brexit would be like this when most didnrsquot know anything about the consequences at all.The whole shambles of Brexit has brought to the table the need for a more sophisticated format for informing the public and then determining what is really the will of the people.Bill Brown, Milngavie.WITH every passing day and twist and turn of this seemingly interminable nightmare of Brexit, Theresa Mayrsquos three times voted-down deals look ever more reasonable and attractive. Unfortunately, extremist-appeasing MPs of every political shade chose instead to pose and put themselves and their party and dogma before doing what was best for the country. Oh, for a little of Mrs Mayrsquos honesty and integrity.Alexander McKay, Edinburgh EH.I VOTED Remain. I shall vote Remain in a second Brexit referendum. I have a satellite issue. If the SNP wins an independence referendum, a second Brexit referendum establishes a precedent for a think-again repeat independence referendum perhaps after two years when the bleak reality of Scottish so called independence has sunk into the Scottish psyche.William Durward, Bearsden.I HAVENrsquoT read the Yellowhammer document on the consequences of no deal, but when I was wee I learned that the yellowhammer sang ldquoA-little-bit-of-bread-and-no-cheeeese. Plus ca change.James Sandeman, Newton Mearns.COULD it be that the UK Government decided to name its preparations for a No Deal Brexit ldquoOperation Yellowhammer because it is aware that all we will have to eat post-Brexit is a little bit of bread and no cheese Andrew Kennedy, Helensburgh.

title: david-cameron-phoned-eu-leaders-apologise-leave-vote
story: The Conservative wrote that he was ldquosad to leave office but even more sad that Britain would be leaving the EU in his memoir which is being serialised in The Times ahead of its publication on Thursday.Another revelation in the book, titled For The Record, was that current PMBoris Johnson asked whether Michael Gove was ldquoa bit cracked after the Brexiteer betrayed him during the  Tory leadership race.Writing about the morning after the Brexit referendum, in which % of people voted to leave the  member bloc, Mr Cameron said he was aware of the ldquoenormity of what happened and that it would ldquostay with me for the rest of my le."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "David Camerons memoirs in  seconds","description": "David Camerons memoirs in  seconds","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media JshDOqN poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests JshDOqN.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Read more:Cameron says second Brexit referendum cannot be ruled outHe added: ldquoThere were phone calls with the other first and deputy first ministers. I spoke to European leaders and to Obama. To each I said the same thing: lsquoI had a strategy to keep Britain in the EU. I executed the strategy. It didnrsquot work. Irsquom sorry.ldquoAs it awaited its next occupants, Downing Street became an eerie place. Power was fading like a dimming lightbulb.ldquoPre-arranged commitments in my diary kept me busy, but I was beginning to feel like the political equivalent of The Walking Dead.The Conservative former prime minister has also recalled the fraught battle to replace him in Number  in his memoir.Mr Gove initially supported Mr Johnsonrsquos campaign but then dramatically withdrew his backing and announced he would stand himself ndash leading the now-PM to quit the contest.As Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, Mr Gove is now responsible for no-deal Brexit preparations in Mr Johnsonrsquos Government, and the revelation could put pressure on his relationship with the PM.The  leadership battle was eventually won by Theresa May, and Mr Cameron revealed in the book how he secretly encouraged Gavin Williamson to help her campaign, according to The Times.Read more:Gordon Brown blames lazy David Cameron for BrexitIn extracts from the book published over the weekend, Mr Cameron took aim at Mr Gove, describing him as a ldquofoam-flecked Faragist.He said Mr Johnson wanted to become the ldquodarling of the Tory party and ldquodidnrsquot want to risk allowing someone  with a high profile ndash Michael Gove in particular ndash to win that crown.Mr Cameron said the Prime Minister ldquodidnrsquot believe in Brexit and only backed the Leave campaign to further his career.ldquoThe conclusion I am left with is that he risked an outcome he didnrsquot believe in because it would help his political career, he wrote.

title: gary-lineker-rachel-riley-new-social-media-pledge-silence-trolls
story: Instead, the group of television stars, politicians and campaigners will be muting, blocking and reporting ldquoabhorrent and derogatory comments ndash with the worst handed to the police ndash in a bid to starve so-called trolls of the wider audience they reportedly crave.The move wants to stamp out entirely those who are using social media to spread racist, sexist, xenophobic and other hateful messaging via retweets and public shaming by well-known figures on social media.Lineker, with his . million Twitter followers, is encouraging fellow social media users: ldquoDonrsquot rise to the bait, block the trolls and take some time out.London Mayor Sadiq Khan, former home secretary Alan Johnson and ex-minister for business Margot James MP are among the politicians to have backed the incentive, while Dragonrsquos Den star Deborah Meaden, Pointless quiz show host Richard Osman, former The Apprentice sidekick Nick Hewer and comedian Aisling Bea have also vowed to no longer engage with trolls.Oh come on! EVERYONErsquos accidentally shared Ku Klux Klan videos before right No  No one  https:t.co ewoOteVmdash Rachel RileySeptember , The public figures have been convinced by new research that suggests hate speech is being inadvertently spread via social media when insults, put downs or worse are quoted or shared.To reverse the worrying trend, the likes of Lineker and Riley have signed-up to instead reporting the worst cases of online abuse and vile messages to the police, while sending lesser examples to social media companies such as Twitter and Facebook to put pressure on them to act.And new charity, the Centre for Countering Digital Hate , the group behind the Donrsquot Feed the Trolls report, is advocating an even simpler solution for those being badgered online ndash it recommends muting notications and taking a break from social media in the first instance, before escalating anything thought to be unlawful.In one eye-opening piece of analysis, a quoted tweet by Labour and anti-Brexit MP David Lammy to his , followers was able to increase his abuserrsquos own popularity by %. The abuser had accused the politician of not being ldquoindigenous English.Lineker, presenter of BBCrsquos Match Of The Day and ex-Tottenham Hotspur goal scorer, said he was determined to ldquoshow online trolls the red card after seeing the racist abuse directed at young black Premier League footballers.Cha striker Tammy Abraham, , admitted his mother was in tears after reading the torrent of racist comments targeted towards him after he missed the decisive penalty in the European Super Cup against Liverpool last month.Fellow England international and Manchester United marksman Marcus Rashford suffered similar backlash after missing a spot-kick against Crystal Palace in a league match this season.Lineker said: ldquoWersquove all been shocked by the way in which racist trolls have been targeting footballers recently.ldquoIt is frankly horrying that they have done so in a calculated way to spread their abhorrent views. Letrsquos not allow the beautul game to be tarnished in this way.ldquoEveryone across the sporting world will be grateful for this guide on how we can show online trolls the red card. Donrsquot rise to the bait, block the trolls and take some time out.CCDHrsquos report ndash co-authored by charity chief executive Imran Ahmed and Dr Linda Papadopoulos, a psychologist featured on television and previously contracted by the Home Office ndash discovered neo-Nazi groups in America had actively encouraged supporters to target public figures in a bid to widen their exposure.The report, published on Monday, contains excerpts from a playbook produced by the US neo-Nazi website, The Daily Stormer, advising that the best way to gain ldquomedia attention and general infamy is ldquoto troll public figures and get them to whine about it.Jewish TV-personality Riley, a former Strictly Come Dancing contestant, has been on the receiving of anti-Semitic abuse and was involved in the research behind the report.She said the experience had ldquototally changed the way I interact on Twitter.ldquoBefore having CCDHrsquos knowledge it felt like not responding to trolls or blocking them was weak, and calling them out, trying to engage in conversation and education was helpful, but the research shows otherwise, said the Celebrity Gogglebox star who has campaigned against anti-semitism in the Labour Party.ldquoI now block trolls as common practice, and have changed my settings to avoid seeing much of their output, which has made le much better from a mental health standpoint and vitally, is not inadvertently helping to grow their audiences or feed their negativity.Mr Khan, Labour mayor of London, encouraged social media users to play their part in tackling online hate.The former minister with Pakistani heritage said: ldquoIrsquove seen first-hand the online hate when social media is hijacked by hateful and cynical users who usually hide behind anonymous accounts.ldquoAll of us who use social media have tremendous power in what we give our attention to and how we react to social media conversations.ldquoBy ignoring, muting or blocking the trolls we can deny them the reactions they seek, while government and social media companies must up their game to ensure it is a safe space for people to exchange ideas.Bea, an Irish comedian and writer of Channel  show This Way Up, previously campaigned in favour legalising abortion in her home country.ldquoWe need to develop and practice our empathy, not just in real le but in our online lives which have escalated without rules of engagement, benefiting no one, she said.Osman ndash host of Twitterrsquos world cup of crisp flavours ndash said: ldquoI love using social media, and I believe it can be a tremendous force for good. The key is to notice the intelligence and kindness, and to ignore the deliberate trolls.ldquoMute them, block them, whatever you need to do. They are hungry for your attention and for your reaction. Donrsquot feed them.

title: alex-salmond-slipperiest-characters-david-cameron-claims
story: In his forthcoming autobiography, For The Record, the former Conservative leader concedes allowing the  referendum to take place was a ldquogamble ndash although he said it would be a ldquomuch bigger gamble to dismiss the issue.After the SNP won an overall majority at Holyrood in , Mr Cameron travelled to Edinburgh to negotiate the terms of the historic ballot.:Mark Smith: A pro-independence majority at Holyrood is not a mandate for another referendum. Itrsquos time we changed the rulesThe former prime minister said: ldquoI went up to Edinburgh for my first negotiation meeting with the slipperiest of characters, Alex Salmond, Scotlandrsquos first minister, in February .ldquoI always used to say you had to count your fingers on the way out of a meeting with him.Mr Cameron had been at Balmoral for an audience with the Queen in the run-up to the referendum when a shock poll put Yes narrowly in the lead.Days later, the Queen urged Scots to ldquothink very carefully about the vote, with Mr Cameron saying he was ldquodelighted by her comments.He wrote: ldquoIf I were the one who precipitated the end of our island story, it would hurt beyond belief.Mr Cameron said there was ldquopanic when the turnout in the referendum ndash which took place almost exactly five years ago on September   ndash was put at almost %, the highest in UK history.He recalled: ldquoAfter Clackmannanshire declared at .am with a solitary majority for no, I went to bed but I didnrsquot sleep.ldquoThe lead we were taking started closing overnight. But sure enough, after am the No votes kept rolling in.ldquoTwo of the happiest hours of my le followed. Everything was going to be OK.Scots voted by % to % against independence, with Mr Salmond announcing within hours of the result being declared that he would be stepping down as SNP leader and first minister.The former first minister said that Mr Cameronrsquos ldquocomments about me seem rather mild compared to the venom he has reserved for his erstwhile Tory chums.:Alex Salmond probe: MSPs seek clarication on court paymentsHe added: ldquoThe extract from his book shows how rattled David Cameron was in the final stages of the  campaign, lying awake at night worrying about what the Queen would think of himthere was a Yes vote!ldquoIn reality David wasnrsquot a great negotiator and the Scottish side achieved most of what we wanted from the Edinburgh Agreement of , hence his petulance even now about the negotiations. Cameronrsquos response was to increasingly let George Osborne do his thinking for him.ldquoIn the end Cameron squeaked through only by combining with the other unionist parties and promising Scots near federal powers in ldquoThe Vow the same type of powers which he previously had refused to even countenance as a possibility. Inevitably these promises were broken by Westminster, which is why five years on independence has become the majority position in Scotland.

story: The RMT union claimed members havehad their working lives ldquoruined and that operators Serco did not address concerns which were raised.Poor staffing levels and insufficient training have down near CarnoustieMembers have been instructed not to book on sht between pm on Sunday September  and .pm on Tuesday October .They have also been told tonot to work any overtime or rest days, not to perform higher-grade duties and to work to their original job description from .am on Wednesday October , until further notice.RMT general secretary Mick Cash said: ldquoThe union is angry and frustrated that promises made to us to address the serious concerns of the Caledonian Sleeper staff at the end of July have not been honoured and that leaves us with no choice but to activate our industrial action mandate.ldquolrmRMT members have been put under intolerable personal stress as a result of the companyrsquos mismanagement of the sleeper service.ldquoThey know it, they have promised to do something about it but they have failed to deliver.ldquoThe move to strike action is entirely Sercorsquos fault and the public will understand that.ldquoThe union remains available for genuine and serious talks.Union representatives have had a number of meetings with the company through the joint working party.They have reported ldquoinsufficient progress has been made and that middle management has been ldquoopenly hostile to finalising a settlement.The operators admitted there have been problems while introducing the new Lowland Sleeper which were ldquochallenging for everyone involved and thanked staff for their efforts.However, they called the action ldquocompletely unnecessary.Ryan Flaherty, Sercorsquos managing director of the Caledonian Sleeper, said: ldquoWe are deeply disappointed and frustrated at this industrial action by the RMT, but most of all we are bemused as they have been unable to explain what will bring this dispute to a resolution.ldquoWe have met the RMT and company council on many occasions and the changes they have requested have either been completed or are under way, including the recruitment of more staff at Edinburgh, Glasgow and London for a six-month period whilst the new Mark  carriages settle in.ldquoThis action is completely unnecessary and we urge the RMT to come back and tell us what they want. We are ready to go to mediation and hold further discussions.

title: herald-diary-nana-nana-no
story: Brush with successTHE son of reader, Graham Dorlan, was grumbling to his dad that he didnrsquot see himself amounting to anything. Whereupon father guided his gurning youngster to the bathroom, and gestured to the dental ware on display. ldquoCheer up, said dad to lad. ldquoIn the last year yoursquove gone from a manual toothbrush to an electric. I think we can safely say yoursquove already transcended your humble origins.Lazy boyANOTHER story of youthful achievement and parental pride. Rita Bradbury wanted to briefly pop down to the local store. Her -year-old son pleaded with her not to go, as he was scared to be home alone. ldquoCome with me, said Rita. Son declined, not fancying the exhausting five-minute stroll to the corner shop. ldquoI was so proud, Rita tells us. ldquoHis laziness trumped his cowardice. My son really has grown up!Dead annoyingMANY well-worn phrases have worn out their welcome. Jan Barker is exasperated by people who say "avoid like the plague". ldquoIf the plague was something that could be avoided, it wouldnrsquot be much of a plague, would it  she argues. Good point. After all, itrsquos unlikely the Black Death could have been dodged by telling everyone to stay in bed a few nights with a box of Kleenex. Pestilence, itrsquos a tad peskier than the snfles.Pot luckWErsquoRE sad to hear of the death of Cafeacute India restauranteur, Abdul Sattar, who did much to popularise Asian cuisine in Glasgow. The Diary scribe, himself, is a lover of a good curry. As a young journalist, I was despatched, one evening, to an Indian restaurant to interview the owner. As the interview wound down, I mentioned, in a nudge-nudge sort of way, that I hadnrsquot eaten all day. Restaurateur looked puzzled for a moment, then smiled benevolently: ldquoNo worries, he said. ldquoTherersquos a Tesco round the corner. You can buy a Pot Noodle to take home. Journalism. It really is that glamorous.Jackrsquos backOUR campaign to introduce modern phobias into medical textbooks continues. Diane Lamb suggests we include her fear of having to read Jack and the Beanstalk to her four- year-old daughter for the thousandth time. ldquoItrsquos my fee-fi-phobia, she says.PoleaxedENDING on a whimsical note, Anne MacLeod jokes: ldquoI recently took a pole and found out  per cent of the occupants were angry when their tent collapsed.Read more: -: Music to the ears of pop fans

title: david-cameron-haunted-eu-referendum-decision
story: In an interview with journalist Tom Bradby on ITV ahead of the publication of his memoirs, Mr Cameron said he is ldquodeeply sorry about all that has happened since the referendum.As part of The Cameron Interview on ITV, the ex-Tory leader was askedthe decision to call the referendum haunted him.He replied: ldquoYeah, of course. You know, this is a huge decision for our country and I think wersquove taken the wrong path. As Irsquove said, it can be made to work.ldquoIf yoursquore asking me, do I have regrets  Yes. Am I sorry about the state the countryrsquos got into  Yes.ldquoDo I feel I have some responsibility for that  Yes. It was my referendum, my campaign, my decision to try to renegotiate.ldquoAnd I accept all of those things and people, including those watching this programme, will have to decide how much blame to put on me.Askedhe would apologise to the country for his actions, Mr Cameron said: ldquoIrsquom deeply sorry about all thatrsquos happened.ldquoThere isnrsquot a day that goes by when I donrsquot think about all the decisions I made and all that has followed."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "David Cameron speaks about Brexit in TV interview","description": "David Cameron speaks about Brexit in TV interview","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media BySOsmai poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests BySOsmai.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": :David Cameron: I phoned EU leaders to apologise after Leave voteldquoBut when I go back to that decision, that Britainrsquos position needed to be sorted and we needed a renegotiation and a referendum, I believed then that was the right approach.Askedhe had any regrets, Mr Cameron said: ldquoI have huge regrets. I regret that we lost the campaign. I regret I let expectations about the negotiation run far too high.ldquoI regret some of the inidual decisions we made in the campaign. I think perhaps therersquos a case to say the timing could have been dferent.The memoirs also reveal the former prime minister rang European leaders and then US president Barack Obama to apologise for his ultimately failed strategy to keep the UK in the EU.Mr Cameron wrote he was ldquosad to leave office but even more sad that Britain would be leaving the EU in his memoir, which is being serialised in The Times ahead of its publication on Thursday.Another revelation in the book, titled For The Record, was that current PMBoris Johnson asked whether Michael Gove was ldquoa bit cracked after the Brexiteer betrayed him during the  Tory leadership race.Writing about the morning after the Brexit referendum, in which % of people voted to leave the -member bloc, Mr Cameron said he was aware of the ldquoenormity of what happened and it would ldquostay with me for the rest of my le.ldquoThere were phone calls with the other first and deputy first ministers, he said.ldquoI spoke to European leaders and to Obama. To each I said the same thing: lsquoI had a strategy to keep Britain in the EU. I executed the strategy. It didnrsquot work. Irsquom sorry.He added: ldquoAs it awaited its next occupants, Downing Street became an eerie place.ldquoPower was fading like a dimming light bulb.:Alex Salmond was lsquoslipperiest of charactersrsquo, David Cameron claimsldquoPre-arranged commitments in my diary kept me busy but I was beginning to feel like the political equivalent of The Walking Dead.The Conservative former prime minister has also recalled the fraught battle to replace him in Number  in his memoir.Mr Gove initially supported Mr Johnsonrsquos campaign but then dramatically withdrew his backing and announced he would stand himself ndash leading the now-PM to quit the contest.As Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, Mr Gove is now responsible for no-deal Brexit preparations in Mr Johnsonrsquos Government, and the revelation could put pressure on his relationship with the PM.The  leadership battle was eventually won by Theresa May and Mr Cameron revealed in the book how he secretly encouraged Gavin Williamson to help her campaign, according to The Times.In extracts from the book published over the weekend, Mr Cameron took aim at Mr Gove, describing him as a ldquofoam-flecked Faragist.He said Mr Johnson wanted to become the ldquodarling of the Tory party and ldquodidnrsquot want to risk allowing someone  with a high profile ndash Michael Gove in particular ndash to win that crown.Mr Cameron said the Prime Minister ldquodidnrsquot believe in Brexit and only backed the Leave campaign to further his career.ldquoThe conclusion I am left with is that he risked an outcome he didnrsquot believe in because it would help his political career, he wrote.

title: diamond celebration for inverurie couple
story: An Inverurie couple have reached a marital milestone.John and Jean Ramage are celebrating  years of marriage.John, , and Jean, , belong to Douglas in Lanarkshire but have spent most of their married le in Inverurie.The couple, who met at a Scout hall party in their home village, tied the knot on March , .They moved to Evanton in Easter Ross before settling in Inverurie in , where John was the local registrar before retiring in the mid s.He was made an MBE in  when convener of the Scottish Association of Health Councils for services to health care. title: call for shops to close on new year s day
story: The shopworkers# trade union is urging all MSPs to back a motion calling for the closure of large shops in New Year#s Day.A survey of Scottish retail staff by the union Usdaw shows overwhelming support for the closure of stores on January .And the union is now calling on all MSPs to support the motion tabled by Jackie Baillie MSP in the Scottish Parliament seeking to ensure shop workers can enjoy some time off at New Year.The survey of more than  shop workers revealed:•  per cent believed stores should close on New Year’s Day, with  per cent saying they should also close on January .• Three quarters feel they spend too little time with friends and family over New Year.•  per cent have come under pressure to work on New Year’s Day or January .• Four in ten don’t receive any premium pay for working on New Year’s Day.•  per cent are not happy to work on New Year’s Day or January .Stewart Forrest, Usdaw’s Scottish isional officer, said: “This survey clearly demonstrates the strength feeling among our members. “We have written to all MSPs asking them to support Jackie Baillie’s motion calling for a decent break at New Year after the busy Christmas period.“I have also written to the Scottish Retail Consortium urging them to reconsider their opposition to large stores closing on New Year’s Day.”Mr Forrest stressed the union was fully supportive of efforts to revitalise our high streets as the livelihoods of its members depended on a thriving retail sector.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.carricktoday webimage ..! title: garioch sports centre serves up an ace with new tennis plans
story: With the nation currently hooked on Wimbledon, it#s a fitting time for Garioch Sports Centre to unveil its new tennis-focused proposals.Inverurie Community Council has submitted fresh expansion plans to Aberdeenshire Council on behalf of Garioch Sports Holdings.Full planning permission was secured last year for a major extension of the Inverurie facility, but changes in the community’s requirements and pressures on funding have prompted a reduced development.Initially the plans would have seen the Burghmuir Drive centre expanding into one of the largest amenities of its kind in Scotland, incorporating tennis courts, a multi-sports arena, fitness suites and an all-weather G pitch for Inverurie Loco Works FC which has now been dropped.But while the scale of the expansion might not be as ambitious, the new plans do reveal tennis courts and improvements for fitness along with an Early Learning Centre for younger children.Thanks to signicant input from Judy Murray – mother of tennis stars Andy and Jamie – the plans feature three dedicated tennis courts and the centre has committed to a three-year partnership with the JM Foundation, highlighting the commitment of the centre to develop the sport across Garioch.The centre and JM Foundation will work in partnership in upskilling their workforce and identying potential coaches while funding coach education.In a supporting statement the centre writes: “The matter of securing the appropriate funding for the ious options which have been considered over the last couple of years has impacted upon how the plans have altered with the focus very much now being on the new tennis provision.“The most recent plans reflect the discussions with the Lawn Tennis Association and also Tennis Scotland.“The advice and guidance of Judy Murray has also been pivotal in how the plans particularly for the tennis courts have progressed.”The applicants also believe that despite the downturn in oil and gas and other industries, there is still a demand for its facilities.It reports: “As many of the activities and programmes now carry waiting lists, there is proof that despite a downturn in many industries the timing is now right to expand in tandem with the growth in participation and the increase in the town and rural residency.“An expansion of the present facility and delivery of its sporting, health and wellbeing activities title: prime minister announces extra funding for scots farmers
story: Scotland#s farming leaders have welcomed #. million of extra funding announced by the Prime Minister on a visit to Aberdeenshire.The cash, over the next two years, is in addition to the £ million package for farmers unveiled earlier this week as part of the Government’s Spending Review.Boris Johnson announced the additional money, recommended in the Bew Review, during a visit to a farm near Banchory where he met NFU Scotland officials.He’d earlier toured Peterhead fishmarket.Speaking after meeting Mr Johnson, NFU Scotland president Andrew McCornick said: “On top of the Chancellor’s welcome announcement in his spending review that Scotland is to receive £ million in convergence funding, we welcome the positive outcome of the Bew Review into future funding allocations and Government’s speedy response to the review’s recommendations.“Taken together, the two announcements will inject £ million into Scottish agriculture over the next two years. At a time of uncertainty, that represents the largest funding uplt for the sector in recent memory.”The Prime Minister is expected to stay overnight at Balmoral before ing south tomorrow. data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Empty windows in the town centre are set to be transformed under the innovative ArtVentre project." title: a waste of money oic homes in on refuse issues
story: Should Orkney deal with its own rubbish rather than paying hundreds of thousands of pounds annually to ship it where That was the question on the lips of several councillors on Tuesday, as they faced a £, overspend in Orkney Islands Council#s waste disposal budget.With the council spending a total of £,, on dumping refuse in the past year, on top of £, to collect it, members of the OIC development and infrastructure committee are keen to find a solution — either by lobbying the Scottish Government for more funding, or by investing in a method of dealing with waste in-house.#We need to find a local solution,# said Kirkwall West and Orphir councillor Leslie Manson, who pointed out that the shipping of waste also contradicted anti-climate change policies.#If we cannot deal with refuse, we have to use lots of fossil fuel to get it where.#He later added: #We have to pay money to ship it where it gets buried for a while. story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. story: Orkney Islands Council is reminding the public about the dangers of incorrectly disposing of gas canisters.This comes as some were found incorrectly disposed of in metal can recycling skips at Hatston Household Waste Recycling Centreon Monday.Environmental services facilities manager for Orkney Islands Council, Jonathan Walters, said: “Never place a gas bottle in with your recycling at the kerbside or at a  Household Waste Recycling Centre , as they could explode when metal cans are crushed to be sent for re-processing and potentially cause serious injury.#There have been recent examples of fires at HWRCs in the UK as a result of people placing metal gas canisters in metal recycling skips”.It is advised toempty gas bottles to the retailer or your original supplier, rather than a HWRC. They will then be collected and refilled for re-use.  Camping gas bottles cannot be recycled however they must not be placed in your general waste bin or a skip.#Return your empty bottles to the retailer or your original supplierthey offer a take back scheme. Failing that, take your empty canisters to a staffed HWRCas hazardous waste to ensure they are disposed of safely.#If you have gas canisters or bottles for disposal or are still unsure, you can contact the Waste Team at Orkney Islands Council on:  Ext  or recycling@orkney.gov.ukcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: liam mcarthur joins great british beach clean
story: Orkney’s MSP, Liam McArthur, will be one of many volunteers helping to clean up Orkney#s coastline later this month as part of a UK-wide beach cleaning event.The Great British Beach Clean is the biggest annual beach clean-up and survey in the UK and is organised by the Marine Conservation Society . The event is now in its th year and MCS hopes to beat what was a record-breaking  with even more beach cleans organised and more volunteers getting involved. Last year, , Scottish volunteers took part, removing an incredible , inidual items of litter at  beach cleans along , metres of Scottish coastline.Data collected by volunteers from over  years of MCS-led Great British Beach Cleans has been instrumental in the introduction of Scotland’s p single-use carrier bag charge, commitments to implement a ban on plastic stemmed cotton buds and to introduce a depositscheme for bottles and cans.Mr McArthur will be joining the citizen science project to help clear and survey the litter found on Echna Loch Bay, Burray on Monday, September .“Orkney has a fine tradition when it comes to ‘bag the bruck’,# says Mr McArthur.#I have been involved in such clean up efforts since I was at school in Sanday.“Of course, these days there is a greater public awareness of marine litter, and concern about the problems caused by plastic pollution in our seas.“I’m looking forward to joining volunteers of all ages at Echna Loch Bay to support the Great British Beach Clean campaign. This will be just one of many such clean ups taking place across the country. As well as helping tidy up our beaches and coastlines, I hope the initiative helps highlight the importance of reducing waste and protecting our precious marine environment”.Lizzie Prior, MCS Beachwatch Officer said: “It’s fantastic to see that local MSP, Liam McArthur, will be joining us at Echna Loch Bay to support our Great British Beach Clean it’s really important for decision-makers to see how much litter, especially plastic, makes its way on to our beaches. We hope that Liam’s attendance at the Great British Beach Clean will encourage local constituents to join us for an eye-opening day on the beaches of Orkney. It#s vital that we all continue to work together to stop the tide of plastic in our oceans.”Constituents looking to join Liam McArthur at the Great British Beach Clean can sign up to volunteer at: www.mcsuk.org greatbritishbeachcleancopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
